title: Is It Okay to Change Your Guru? Spiritual Guidance Explained
content:
**Is It Okay to Change Your Guru? Spiritual Guidance Explained**

---

### The Question of Faith and Spiritual Exploration

A common spiritual dilemma arises when a person, deeply devoted to one form of worship or one guru, finds themselves drawn to another temple, another path, or even another religion. Does this shift weaken their spiritual progress? Does it mean their faith is fragile or flawed?

The answer, offered with clarity and compassion, is a resounding **no**.

If your faith is so fragile that visiting another place of worship causes you to stray, then the foundation of that faith was not strong to begin with. True faith is not diminished by exposure to other truths; it is tested and can be strengthened by it.

> “And wherever you are going, only good is happening. In the gurudwara, only prayers are happening. Sacred verses are being recited. In the temple, only good things are being spoken. If we try to create differences, if we think, ‘This is different, that is different,’ then what have we truly gained from our spiritual practice so far? What have we attained?”

This perspective is presented as a core strength of the Sanatana Dharma (the eternal path), which holds all religions in equal respect. A sincere seeker learns something good from everyone.

---

### The Parable of the Well: Depth Over Distance

A powerful analogy is shared to illustrate the importance of consistency:

> “If we have to draw water, we must dig a well in one place. We just have to keep at it there. Keep digging, keep digging.”

A student then posed a beautiful, logical question: “If I keep digging, won’t the water eventually come out? I’ll keep digging and it will emerge, right?”

The response reframes the metaphor from one of guaranteed immediacy to one of certain eventual success, regardless of location:

> “My belief is this: even if you go to Mount Everest and start digging, it might not come out at 1000 feet. It might come out at 5,000 or 7,000 feet. But it **will** come out, without a doubt.”

The key is not the specific patch of ground, but the act of committed digging. If you move from one guru to another, you should never bring a feeling of inferiority or guilt into your heart.

> “You cannot force an attachment with anyone. You cannot force love with anyone. If, for any reason, your mind has moved on, you have grown… you have grown out of your guru's teachings—what is wrong with it?”

---

### A Guru’s Perspective: Freedom Over Followers

From the other side of the relationship, a truly enlightened guide seeks the disciple’s freedom, not their perpetual dependence.

> “In fact, with everyone I initiate, I always take one promise from them. That promise is: the day you have doubt about me, and if that doubt remains for a week, then abandon me. Then we are done with each other.”

The reasoning is profound and selfless. The goal is not to maintain a relationship at all costs, but to keep it pure. The guru’s happiness lies in the disciple’s progress and peace, not in their physical presence.

> “I will be very happy when you go to someone else. What does it mean? It means that you remain happy and joyous in life and keep progressing. I have little to do with you continuing to come to me. What do I have to gain from that? If you are happy, content, then my job is done.”

The ultimate success for a guru is the day the disciple no longer *needs* to come to them, when the seeker finds their own inner stillness. This separation is not born of ego (“I don’t need you”), but from a genuine realization of self-sufficiency, which arrives slowly and gracefully.

---

### Why the Shift Happens: A Two-Way Dynamic

If a seeker feels compelled to move on, where does the responsibility lie? The explanation is refreshingly balanced.

It could be that the guru lacked a certain magnetic quality to hold the disciple. Or, more positively, it could be that the disciple themselves has grown so much that they have become a powerful magnet themselves.

> “Or you yourself have become such a magnet that when you faced him, you both moved apart. North faces north, and now you are going apart.”

When spiritual progress happens, one should feel free, as if moving from one school to another for further specialization. If the guru’s community instills a sense of guilt, suggesting you are leaving due to a “lack of surrender,” that is incorrect.

Surrender cannot be forced. If the heart is not in it, forcing it creates misery for everyone—the disciple, the guru, and even the divine.

> “Then you are unhappy, the guru is unhappy, and God is unhappy thinking, ‘He doesn’t call me with joy anymore. Before, he would at least pray with feeling. Now, he doesn’t at all.’”

---

### The Doctor-Patient Metaphor: Knowing When You’re Cured

Life, and the spiritual path, should not be lived with excessive sensitivity. One must be a little firm.

A simple, powerful metaphor is offered:

> “My work is done. Now I am leaving. If the disease is gone, why keep reporting to the same doctor?”

Most people on the spiritual path have one core “disease”—suffering, ignorance, discontent. Once the remedy is found and the disease is cured, there’s no need for constant visits to the doctor.

> “At most, remember the doctor on Diwali, wish them a Happy New Year, and if you forget something, you can ask. But nothing more than that.”

---

### The Real Difference Between Guru and Disciple

Is the guru inherently different? The answer demystifies the guru’s position.

> “Do you not have a guru within you? You do. If there is any fundamental difference between me and you… I’m just joking. But if there is any fundamental difference, it is only this: I have worked hard for this position. You have not yet worked as hard. I walked with a resolution and discipline. You have not walked as much yet. I don’t see any other difference.”

The distinction is not one of inherent divinity, but of **clarity, priority, and disciplined effort**. The guru had clear priorities, knew what they wanted, and structured their life accordingly. The disciple may have made different choices earlier and now must rectify them with more effort.

---

### The Spiritual Lottery: Are You a Spender or an Investor?

This leads to a crucial introspection about our deepest desires, illustrated by the “spiritual lottery.”

If you ask people what they would do if they won a massive lottery, almost all will talk about spending: a bigger house, a luxury car, a world tour.

> “If you ask them, ‘If you get a lot of wealth, what will you do?’ the first thing that comes to everyone's mind is a list of expenses. History is witness that 90% of people who win the lottery become poorer than before within 10 years. They blow all the money.”

Everyone wants God—the ultimate lottery. They want divine vision, realization, and experience. But their mind is focused only on the “expenses”: “May this problem be solved, may that wish be fulfilled.”

> “You have to decide. Do you want to spend or do you want to save?”

If a person’s mind, even before “winning” the spiritual lottery, is only filled with a list of desires to be fulfilled, they will not find happiness even if grace descends upon them. Their mind is in one place (desires) and the prize is in another (liberation). Until these two are aligned, attainment is impossible.

The speaker shares their own journey:

> “In my life, I aligned those two first. My passion was only for this. And one more reason is that, in the context of spiritual attainment, compared to that, everything else in life seemed very easy to me… If my spiritual journey was an ocean, everything else I did in life, all put together, was just a drop.”

The goal, then, is to stop chasing the lottery and to **become the lottery machine itself**, able to generate your own winning numbers—your own peace and fulfillment—at will.

---

### Conclusion: A Message of Confidence and Freedom

The final message is one of unwavering confidence and freedom.

> “So, one should never be nervous. Whether moving from one guru to another, or from one place of worship to another… I can only speak for myself. Wherever I go, I receive the same joy.”

Our faith must be strong. What we take from which religion is our own choice. Every religious scripture has some good things, and some things that seem impossible in the modern age.

> “Take what feels good to you.”

A final, humorous story drives home the point of how the mind can be skillfully managed, concluding that the mind can be convinced of anything. The path is not about forcing the mind into submission, but about understanding it, guiding it, and ultimately, freeing it.

In the end, changing your guru is not a sign of failure, but a potential sign of growth. It is a step on the personal, unique, and ultimately liberating journey back to yourself.
